intro: Balaniella fasciculata, commonly known as the clustered broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its yellow flowers and absence of true leaves. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid regions, often found in association with shrubs and grasses. Its unique reproductive strategy involves producing numerous small, dry seeds that can remain dormant in the soil for extended periods. Due to its parasitic nature, it plays a significant role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat.
